$comment: This file contains manually researched category compliance rules. During alpha, we maintain these as versioned JSON files. Each entry should be researched using external tools (Perplexity, GPT, etc.) and follow the same structure. Rename this file to category_rules.json after adding your first real entries.

categories.label: Baby Teether / Infant Teething Toys
testingRequirements: Third-party lab testing for CPSIA compliance required
Lead content must be below 100 ppm
Small parts testing to ensure no choking hazards
Tensile strength testing for silicone products
highRiskFlags: Products for children under 3 years old are high-risk
Colorants must be non-toxic and FDA-approved
No BPA, PVC, or phthalates allowed
Import holds are common if testing documentation is missing

categories.label: Stainless Steel Tumbler / Water Bottle
testingRequirements: Stainless steel grade verification (should be 304 or 316)
Leak-proof testing for bottles with lids
Dishwasher safety testing (if claiming dishwasher safe)
highRiskFlags: Must use food-grade stainless steel (304 or 316)
Any coating or lining must be FDA-approved for food contact
Custom logos/printing must use food-safe inks
Vacuum seal integrity is critical for insulation claims

categories.label: Silicone Baby Teether Toy

requiredRegulations.name: CPSIA - Total Lead in Substrate
requiredRegulations.details: The total lead content in any accessible substrate material of a children's product must not exceed 100 parts per million (ppm).

requiredRegulations.name: CPSIA - Phthalates
requiredRegulations.details: Children's toys and child care articles must not contain more than 0.1% of eight specified phthalates (DEHP, DBP, BBP, DINP, DIBP, DPENP, DHEXP, DCHP).

requiredRegulations.name: CPSIA - Tracking Information
requiredRegulations.details: Product and its packaging must have permanent, distinguishing marks indicating the manufacturer, production date, and cohort information (batch, lot).

requiredRegulations.name: Children's Product Certificate (CPC)
requiredRegulations.details: A statement of compliance, self-issued by the importer or domestic manufacturer, certifying that the product complies with all applicable U.S. children's product safety rules based on passing results from a CPSC-accepted third-party laboratory.

requiredRegulations.name: Standard for Toy Safety
requiredRegulations.details: Compliance with the mandatory safety standard for toys, which covers numerous hazards including mechanical (small parts, sharp points/edges) and chemical (heavy elements).
requiredRegulations.citation: ASTM F963-17 (as mandated by 16 CFR Part 1250)

requiredRegulations.name: Small Parts Regulation
requiredRegulations.details: Prohibits small parts in toys and other articles intended for children under 3 years of age which present a choking, aspiration, or ingestion hazard.

requiredRegulations.name: Total Lead in Paint & Surface Coatings
requiredRegulations.details: The lead content in paint or similar surface coatings on a children's product must not exceed 90 ppm.

requiredRegulations.name: FDA - Food Contact Material
requiredRegulations.details: As teethers are intended for oral use, the silicone must comply with FDA regulations for 'Rubber articles intended for repeated use' to ensure no harmful substances migrate from the material.

requiredRegulations.name: California Proposition 65
requiredRegulations.details: Requires businesses to provide warnings to Californians about significant exposures to chemicals that cause cancer, birth defects or other reproductive harm. Requires either testing for listed chemicals or applying a warning label.
requiredRegulations.citation: California Health and Safety Code Section 25249.6

testingRequirements: Third-party testing at a CPSC-accepted laboratory is mandatory for children's products to support a Children's Product Certificate (CPC).
ASTM F963-17 Mechanical Hazards: Use and abuse testing (drop, torque, tension, compression), small parts testing (before and after abuse), sharp edges and points testing.
ASTM F963-17 Section 4.22 Teethers and Teething Toys: Specific tests for structural integrity, protrusions, and to ensure they do not break into hazardous small parts.
ASTM F963-17 Soluble Heavy Elements: Testing for the migration of 8 elements (Antimony, Arsenic, Barium, Cadmium, Chromium, Lead, Mercury, Selenium).
Total Lead Content in Substrate (CPSC-CH-E1002-08.3 for non-metals).
FDA 21 CFR 177.2600 Extraction Testing: To ensure no harmful chemicals migrate from the silicone when in contact with solvents simulating saliva.
Age Grading Verification: The product must be appropriately age-graded (e.g., 3+ months) and tested according to the standards for that age group.
highRiskFlags: Small Part Detachment: Components or pieces of the teether breaking off during use or testing, creating a choking hazard.
Material Non-Compliance: Use of industrial-grade or recycled silicone instead of 100% food-grade silicone, leading to chemical contamination.
Molding Defects: Sharp edges or points ('flashing') left over from the injection molding process that can cut a baby's mouth.
Incorrect or Forged Test Reports: Supplier provides a test report that is for a different product, is expired, or is from a non-CPSC-accepted lab.
Liquid-Filled Teether Failure: Risk of puncture, leakage, and bacterial contamination if the teether contains a liquid or gel component.
